lines.text: Cheyenne, you ain't serious, are you? Killin' me don't make sense.

[lronically]
It never does to the fella that's getting killed.

[Referring to the gallows being built for Nitro and Cheyenne]
Only twelve hours until you boys get some exercise... walking on air.
I'm crazy about you, Jack. Are you crazy about me?
I'd be crazy if I was.
You ought to knock before coming in here, Countess. Suppose I was taking a bath or something?
If I ever hear of you taking a bath, I'll start knocking.
Nitro, did you ever want to live your life over again?
Me? No, I couldn't stand the excitement twice in a row.

[toasting]
Here's to green pastures and no fences!
Three men murdered in cold blood! What's the sense to it?
We was robbin' a bank!
I'm a lot older than you, Jack. In my time, I've seen a lot of men with itchy trigger fingers like you - and they're all in Boot Hill with dirt in their face. Somebody cured them of that itch.
Would you like a couple of holes in that big fat belly of yours?

[leaving]
You're holdin' up the U.S. mail, amd that's a Federal offense.
Are you sure you can't remember anything about him, Allison?
Yes, Steve. The way I remember him, he couldn't come out last in a gunfight. He seems awful quick, Steve.
Did you ever see how fast I can duck?
Why, I aim to give Red Valley a couple hangings that they'll be proud of in days to come!
Come on, let's go!
Well, why? What's the hurry? We're not in any hurry.
Oh, yes, we are. I just robbed a bank!

...Four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve. Well, gents, there's twelve of you, and it takes twelve to make a jury. Now we got two men here to hang. But we are going to do it by the law. Hank, you be foreman.
Huh? Oh, all right, judge.
Lift your right hand. Do you solemnly swar to put the law on them bank robbers, so help ya?
I do.
That's the stuff, Hank! Now wait a minute, we got to have a little evidence... but very little!
I was just goin' down to look at my horse.
Steve was in to see his horse a little while ago.

[laughs]
Seems like there thee ain't nuthin' more lonesome than a lonesome horse.

[Uncle Willy laughs again]
Except maybe a lonesome man.
A man don't need to be if the saloon's open.
A man can't do much when he gets old except save his money.

[leaving with Cheyenne as Willie sits on front porch]
Good night, Uncle Willie.
Through with your courtin', boys?
For tonight... yeah.
[He laughs]

[philisophically]
Ah, havin' a daughter's a real trial. Man with a son can get all the sleep he needs, but with a daughter you can't close your eyes 'til everyone's gone home.
[Steve laughs]

[referring to Cheyenne]
Real bang-up outlaw they say... dangerous afoot, on a horse, or layin' on his back. Wouldn't think so quiet-spoken a fellas as him is bad would yuh?
They say he's a good badman.
There ain't no such thing. A bad man's bad for himself and for everybody else.
